content.text:
Comprensión auditiva.

En esta parte, usted escuchará preguntas o enunciados en inglés seguidos de tres opciones, también en inglés. Las preguntas o enunciados y las opciones se dirán solo una vez. Escuche cuidadosamente para poder entender porque no aparece nada escrito en el folleto de examen para estos ejercicios. Seleccione la mejor opción para cada pregunta o enunciado y oscurezca el espacio de la letra correspondiente en la hoja de respuestas.

3th4

content.text: Explicación: Para contestar este ejercicio, es necesario entender que “How do you feel?” se refiere a los sentimientos, al estado de ánimo, así que la única respuesta aceptable es (A) “sad” que significa triste.

content.text: Recuerde que en estos ejercicios no aparece nada escrito en el folleto del examen.
content.name: 6Zyx

content.class: bg-slate-200 w-8 h-8 text-xl text-slate-400  rounded text-center ml-1 mr-5
content.name: Bk8u

content.text: ________ house is the want I want to buy. It’s the white one, behind the tree.
content.name: BdfR

content.text: A)
content.name: 3NEx

content.text: This
content.name: aAkT

content.text: B)
content.name: dxmm

content.text: That
content.name: cREL

content.text: C)
content.name: r6sp

content.text: These
content.name: yLE2

content.text: D)
content.name: qBZg

content.text: Those
content.name: 4boL

content.text: Contestación: (B)
content.name: Zl5U

content.text: Explicación: Para contestar este ejercicio es necesario determinar si el sujeto es singular o plural. En este caso, es singular “house”, lo cual elimina las posibilidades  (C) y (D) que son plurales. Luego debemos determinar si la casa está cerca o lejos. Si hablamos de que la casa está atrás de un árbol, significa que está lejos, así que la única respuesta correcta es “that”.

content.text: Ejemplo:
content.name: sNYy

content.text:
Los ejercicios 9-16 se basan en el siguiente párrafo. La primera oración pertenece al ejemplo.

Marissa knew she was in trouble. The last time she (9) ________to therapy, she knew she had to (10) _______the truth to her parents. Her parents (11) ___________ paying for college for almost three years, (12) _______she decided she didn't want to study medicine. She became a kindergarten teacher. Teaching was her (13) ________, and she honestly thought she was born to teach and help young learners have a pleasant experience in their early education. When she was little, she (14) ________ play "school" with her siblings and cousins. She (15) ________ be the teacher, and her siblings and cousins acted out as students. Her parents had planned a different life for her, saving money for her to become a doctor, just like her father. They were really proud when she got accepted (16) _____ med school and gave her a brand-new car when she finished her first semester.
content.name: QY2N

content.class: bg-slate-200 w-8 h-8 text-xl text-slate-400  rounded text-center ml-1 mr-5

content.name: gp6e

content.text: B)
content.name: t1ye

content.text: Were

content.text: C)
content.name: 4Eh0

content.text: Was
content.name: EpUY

content.text: D)
content.name: K6xD

content.text: Has
content.name: oy71

content.text: Contestación: (C)
content.name: w3au

content.text: Explicación: En este caso, estamos hablando de un relato en el pasado, por lo cual, nuestra respuesta forsozamente debe ser en pasado. Ahora, cuando la persona es segunda persona del singular, debe ser “was”, por lo que nuestra única respuesta aceptable es la (C), was.

content.text: Contestación: (A)

content.text: Explicación: La oración (B) es correcta pero incompleta, ya que le falta información, al igual que la (D), que no tiene la información de cuándo fue que el gato se enfermó. Las palabras en la alternativa (C) no están en orden. Solamente la alternativa (A) combina las oraciones con toda la información en el orden correcto.

content.class: bg-slate-100 rounded p-3 my-2 max-w-3xl mx-auto

content.textual:
*María got her high school diploma.\nShe got her high school diploma in May.\nShe wants to take a break.
Choose the alternative that is closest in meaning to the following sentences.
Maria got in May her high school diploma and wants a break.
Maria got her high school diploma in May and wants to take a break.
Maria wants to take a break. In May she got her high school diploma.
Maria got her high school diploma in May.
b

*Luisa and Karina are talented.\nThey are my friends.\nThey go to the club.\nLuisa and María play tennis.
Choose the alternative that is closest in meaning to the following sentences.
Luisa and Karina go to the club and play tennis.
They go to the club Luisa and Karina to play tennis and they are my friends.
 My talented friends Luisa and Karina go to the club to play tennis.
I have talented friends who go to the club to play tennis.
c

*The kids are in the park.\nThe kids are playing soccer.\nThe kids are tired.
Choose the alternative that is closest in meaning to the following sentences.
The tired kids are in the park playing soccer.
The kids are playing soccer and tired.
The kids are in the park and tired.
They are playing in the park, and they are tired.
a

*Isaac is a dentist.\nIsaac works from Monday to Friday.\nIsaac loves his job.\nIsaac is tired and wants to retire soon.
Choose the alternative that is closest in meaning to the following sentences.
Isaac wants to retire from his job, and he works Monday to Friday as a dentist.
Isaac is a dentist who works from Monday to Friday and wants to retire soon.
Isaac, a dentist who loves his job, works from Monday to Friday and wants to retire soon.
Isaac wants to retire soon; he is a dentist and loves his job.
c

*Daria wants to go to the party.\nHer parents didn’t give her permission.\nShe has an important exam tomorrow.
Choose the alternative that is closest in meaning to the following sentences.
Daria wants to go to the party, but her parents didn’t give her permission because she has an important exam tomorrow. 
Daria doesn’t have permission to go to the party because she has an important exam.
Daria wants to go to the party btu she has an important exam tomorrow.
Daria has an important exam tomorrow because she can’t go to eh party.
a

*My parents heard my speech.\nMy parents are proud.\nThey want to take me out for lunch.
Choose the alternative that is closest in meaning to the following sentences.
My parents are proud of me and want to go to have lunch.
My parents heard my speech and are so proud of me that want to take me out for lunch.
My parents want to take me out for lunch because they are proud of me.
 My parents and I are going to have lunch because I gave a nice speech.
b

*Insulin is a hormone.\nThe pancreas makes insulin.\nInsulin helps glucose in your blood enter cells in your muscle. \nInsulin in blood is used for energy.
Choose the alternative that is closest in meaning to the following sentences.
Insulin is a hormone made by the pancreas that helps glucose in your blood enter muscle, where it’s used for energy.
Insulin is energy that the muscles need to enter the blood hormones.
Insulin is a hormone made by the pancreas; we use it for energy in our muscles.
Muscles are the ones that use insulin as energy because the pancreas helps them enter the cells.
a
content.name: cWdC
4pSO

content.text: Ejemplo:
content.name: j4J1

content.text: Los ejercicios 34-40 se basan en la siguiente lectura:
content.name: EVm8

content.text:
(1)In some companies, people at the top decide to do team-building activities to improve their atmosphere. (2) ________, talking to business people around me, I’ve heard many stories of team-building practices that could have gone better. (3)There is an entire industry _______ the provision of team-building activities, exercises, and events.
(4) For example, many people reported feeling anger and resentment about four junior colleagues who had been promoted over the rest of the team, and the negative feelings were affecting work badly.
(5) The manager invited everyone to a full day out of the office for a team-building activity: paintballing. (6) Many workers saw it as an opportunity for revenge against their friends.
(7) The activity didn't result in any improvement at work, and it made the team members feel scarier. (8) The outcome of this story is ____ I recommend managers choose their activities more carefully. (9) People need group therapy.
content.name: dB9r

content.class: bg-slate-200 w-8 h-8 text-xl text-slate-400  rounded text-center ml-1 mr-5
content.name: mWT0

content.text: Which sentence does not belong in the text?
content.name: HAgg

content.text: A)
content.name: PSkj

content.text: B)
content.name: bh6S

content.text: C)
content.name: 8JHN

content.text: D)
content.name: dTgZ

content.text: Contestación: C
content.name: m7vr

content.text: Explicación: Para contestar este ejercicio es necesario leer todo el texto. Luego lea de nuevo cada una de las oraciones. El hecho de que la gente deba ir a terapia (oración 9) no tiene nada que ver directamente con el hecho de que las actividades de integración deben ser elegidas correctamente. Por consiguiente, esa es la oración que no pertenece al texto.
content.name: rwcX

3
5
7 
8

However

in

Nevertheless

The word “companies” in sentence 1

nevertheless

Comprensión de lectura y vocabulario.

En los siguientes ejercicios, se presenta un párrafo con algunas partes subrayadas. Después de leerlo, seleccione la opción con un significado similar al de la parte subrayada. Oscurezca el espacio de la letra correspondiente en la hoja de respuestas.

content.text: Ejemplo:
content.name: zZdq

content.class: p-5 rounded-lg bg-sky-100 grid grid-cols-10 gap-5

content.text: Los ejercicios 1-5 se basan en el siguiente párrafo.
content.name: 8IoI

content.text: Do you know when the new TV is coming up? I hope the prices go down a
content.name: r6zd

content.text: bit as they skyrocketed two years ago when TVs became more intelligent
content.name: xmvg

content.text: than they really were. I can't tell the difference between different models;
content.name: NwpC

content.text: they look all the same to me, but these new models feature allows me to
content.name: QgYL

content.text: scroll up and down just using my hands. Exactly, not my fingers with the
content.name: Mtko

content.text: remote, my hands.
content.name: VVTd

content.text: Most housewives may have a cool reception to the idea of having a new TV
content.name: sjtB

content.text: in the house because they say they could have more shoes or save for a
content.name: IpdZ

content.text: trip. However, sometimes you have to stick your neck out and buy it! Or you
content.name: 5ds6

content.text: could play it safe and make a negotiation. That's up to you.
content.name: NTxL
EehI

content.class: bg-slate-200 w-8 h-8 text-xl text-slate-400  rounded text-center ml-1 mr-5
content.name: FFta

content.text: What time does Mary have dinner?
content.name: WWTl

content.text: A)
content.name: 05Qv

content.text: Go out
content.name: Qosh

content.text: B)
content.name: 7xSs

content.text: sell
content.name: 0Fso

content.text: C)
content.name: GH83

content.text: Be released
content.name: dXYY

content.text: D)
content.name: gzNP

content.text: be replaced
content.name: 56L6

content.text: Contestación: (C)
content.name: upSH

content.text: Explicación: Para contestar este ejercicio es necesario leer todo el texto y luego volver a la línea 1. La expresión idiomática “come up”significa “surgir”o “emerger”, dentro de este contexto habla de un producto que va a salir. Se está hablando de un nuevo modelo de televisión.
content.name: GxaX
QEDH

content.class: bg-slate-100 rounded p-3 my-2 max-w-3xl mx-auto

content.textual:
In line 2, “skyrocketed” means.
The price increased rapidly.
A rocket went to the sky.
Prices went up.
Prices need to change.
A

In line 5, the idiomatic expression “scroll up” means.
To move down to the top of the page
To move around the page
To move up to the top of the page
To move to another page
C

In line 7, the expression “cool reception” means.
To reject it
To say welcome
To receive it
To be happy about it
A

In line 9, the expression “stick your head out” means.
To say what you think
To take your neck out
To get in a fight
To enjoy 
A

In line 10, the expression “play it safe” means. 
To take risks
To stay safe at home
To take care of what you think
To avoid risks.
D

p-5 rounded-lg bg-sky-100 grid grid-cols-10 gap-5

content.text: Los ejercicios 6-9 se basan en la siguiente lectura:
content.name: p2Ch

content.text: It was a cold night in Alaska; I didn't know what to do as I stood there
content.name: HerG

content.text: shivering in the frigid air.
content.name: 0UiS

content.text: I wondered how I would survive the brutal Alaskan winter. The wind howled
content.name: htVo

content.text: through the trees, and snow swirled around me, making me feel like I was
content.name: F6cU

content.text: trapped in a frozen wasteland. In the end, it had been my decision to make
content.name: Mfpg

content.text: that trip, to leave home, my job, and everything I had, and move to the
content.name: D7jE

content.text: middle of nowhere. For some people, it may have been a wild decision,
content.name: irdS

content.text: but for me, it was exactly what I needed after that terrible event, the event
content.name: wg7f

content.text: that made me realize I had to run away from my enemies. I was looking for
content.name: aiq2

content.text: revenge, but it was poisoning my soul.
content.name: jJ9J

content.text: The night I lost my family was two years ago when one of my coworkers
content.name: foiW

content.text: tried to murder me due to some secrets I discovered about the new
content.name: S3i8

content.text: project the government was about to launch. They thought they would kill
content.name: uAaM

content.text: me, but they ended up destroying everyone I loved. So, in a way, they
content.name: F49Y

content.text: destroyed me.
content.name: lLyb

content.text: This one night, I started walking without direction, and I got lost. I knew I had
content.name: lace

content.text: to find shelter soon or risk freezing to death. As I trudged through the
content.name: 9rDZ

content.text: snow, I prayed for a miracle, some sign of hope to guide me through the
content.name: b9D1

content.text: darkness. But all I heard was the sound of my footsteps crunching on the icy
content.name: Zwuc

content.text: ground.
content.name: Mnbv

content.text: I wanted to shout, but I knew no one would hear the hopeless voice of
content.name: u4BJ

content.text: someone like me, and even if they did, I was just a stranger with no
content.name: PcnM

content.text: name, with some wrinkles on my face and a secret I could not reveal, as it
content.name: KKVN

content.text: would be dangerous for anyone that heard it.
content.name: ikcl
vflq

content.textual:
How does the narrator feel?
Hopeless
Happy
Angry
sad
A

What does he refer to when he says “frozen wasteland” in line 3?
A frozen place to live.
A very cold place.
Vast parts of uninhabited parts of land covered by snow and ice.
He was freezing in that place.
B

Why did he decide to go to that place?
Someone was trying to murder him.
He had a secret and he wanted to publish it.
He needed to find shelter.
He had a secret from his former company.
A

What event does he refer to in line 6?
Moving to the middle of nowhere.
The day someone destroyed his family.
The day he learned about the secret.
The day he had wrinkles on his face.
D

adxw

p-5 rounded-lg bg-sky-100 grid grid-cols-10 gap-5

content.text: Los ejercicios 10-17 se basan en la siguiente lectura:
content.name: NEvi

content.text: People who do business know that the world is a dangerous place in
content.name: HXuT

content.text: general, and there is risk when it comes to doing business. If a company
content.name: Q6Vk

content.text: wants to survive this scary world, it is vital to identify and manage possible
content.name: aInT

content.text: risks.
content.name: dWyF

content.text: This is what we do every day, and we do it automatically. Before walking
content.name: 42Ag

content.text: on the streets, we always look around to ensure there aren’t cars coming
content.name: VMEH

content.text: towards us. When you become a parent, you consistently high up all the
content.name: paUl

content.text: potential dangers before letting your children run the risk of riding a bike on
content.name: aPrU

content.text: the street. We even do this when it comes to simple things like going to the
content.name: An5o

content.text: gym or choosing a couple. Some people even make lists of pros and
content.name: Ewk0

content.text: cons regarding their future lives with that special someone.
content.name: sKVg

content.text: There are some risks that affect all types of businesses, such as inflation,
content.name: KVwC

content.text: which is something we can’t control, security, government regulations, and
content.name: Daem

content.text: taxation, amongst others.
content.name: 413O

content.text: As previously stated, there are some risks that affect all types of
content.name: XSUn

content.text: businesses. However, there are some risks that affect different sectors; for
content.name: 4TFg

content.text: example, products that are out of stock in retail can become a reason why a
content.name: ZjNc

content.text: shop could go bankrupt. Or what recently happened in car dealership
content.name: poVh

content.text: companies as there was a shortage of chips to control the electronics. The
content.name: pCeY

content.text: telecommunications sector has always been a changing spot, and
content.name: f2BE

content.text: mobile companies must anticipate shifting customer tastes in the market.
content.name: g61x

content.text: This market has moved so fast during the past 20 years that it’s hard to look
content.name: wuZE

content.text: one year into the future.
content.name: 0Qjz

content.text: As part of evolution and being able to survive as a species, we know that the
content.name: vDlE

content.text: ones that survive are the ones that are most responsive to change. The
content.name: OTHA

content.text: problem with risk assessment is that we cannot predict how and when these
content.name: oTf2

content.text: changes are coming.
content.name: f4NG

content.text: Some software accepts various inputs that can produce graphics to allow
content.name: 1DQg

content.text: you to view multiple risks at a glance, all as a part of an interactive timeline.
content.name: h7Ed

content.text: We can evaluate the potential impact of upcoming artificial intelligence
content.name: 5h4i

content.text: technologies, but these are still on trial. We will know what to do in the
content.name: ZfMY

content.text: following months and years.
content.name: kpEz
BjP8

content.textual:
What is the purpose of this text?
To inform
To express and opinion
To persuade
To express feelings
A

“This” in line 5 refers to…
New technology
Identifying managing possible risks
People making lists of pros and cons
Risks in businesses
B

In line 7, “high up” refers to…
Consider, analyze.
Weight out
Research
Tell people about risks
A

In the text, how many types of risks does the author mention?
Five
Four
Eight
Two
D

In line 19, what does the word “shortage of chips” refer to:
Companies were not producing sufficient materials to make cars.
There were more than enough chips to make cars.
The creation of strategies to build more chips.
Chips were lost in the production of cars.
A

In line 29, “at a glance” could be changed for:
A view
Briefly 
Carefully
slowly
B

This text was written by:
An engineer
A poet
A business expert
A software creator
C

This text is aimed for:
Business people
Everybody
Engineers
Students 
A
content.name: wFHN
b3Iu

content.class: bg-slate-100 rounded p-3 my-2 max-w-3xl mx-auto
p-5 rounded-lg bg-sky-100 grid grid-cols-10 gap-5

content.text: Los ejercicios 18-25 se basan en la siguiente lectura:
content.name: zjMV

content.text: "Stress is bad for you" is something we usually hear regarding health.
content.name: wOBK

content.text: Indeed, there are symptoms of stress we can't ignore, and it is proven
content.name: XKN5

content.text: chronic stress is a cause of many major health problems, such as heart
content.name: aHAC

content.text: disease and cancer.
content.name: xjo6

content.text: Stress is a natural or automatic response developed in our ancestors to
content.name: sbmV

content.text: protect us from predators and other threats. Whenever we face danger, our
content.name: 5SD6

content.text: bodies kick into gear and release stress hormones such as adrenaline and
content.name: fMvF

content.text: cortisol that elevate our heart rate, increase our blood pressure, and prepare
content.name: uviW

content.text: us to deal with the problem.
content.name: OD4V

content.text: In modern days, we are not in danger of being eaten by a lion, but we
content.name: UaYB

content.text: must deal with multiple challenges daily. Challenges that go from simple, like
content.name: PsJk

content.text: driving our car to work, organizing our schedule, cooking a meal, to complex
content.name: qHSR

content.text: ideas, like setting up a business, being mugged, paying bills and taxes.
content.name: k5IE

content.text: Simple and complex challenges make our bodies react the same
content.name: y7eT

content.text: way, known as a "fight or flight" response: our body's natural alarm
content.name: nEGQ

content.text: system. This can have severe consequences for our health.
content.name: w7wv

content.text: We ignore this, but minor stress can have an impact; for example, giving a
content.name: B8HV

content.text: presentation can cause a stomachache, and more stress, caused by a
content.name: PuQe

content.text: hurricane, can have a more significant effect.
content.name: KZ81

content.text: Repeated high-stress situations can cause inflammation in the
content.name: 3RWw

content.text: circulatory system and high cholesterol levels.
content.name: rER5

content.text: The longer the stress lasts, it becomes a part of your life and harms your
content.name: ZCbU

content.text: mind and body. You may suffer from chronic fatigue, inability to focus, or
content.name: QCMQ

content.text: being irritable without a reason. We also know that stress can cause wear
content.name: hPQU

content.text: and tear on our bodies.
content.name: GPj3

content.text: Living under stress for an extended period of time can cause physical and
content.name: m6r7

content.text: mental problems, such as anxiety, depression, digestive issues, headaches,
content.name: cy3q

content.text: stroke, sleep problems, weight gain, and memory issues.
content.name: Zsht

content.text: It has been proven that stress makes us change our habits, and there are
content.name: axEa

content.text: changes we make in our routines to cope with stress, such as smoking,
content.name: CAXY

content.text: eating ultra-processed food, or drinking alcohol, which harm our bodies even
content.name: JFnO

content.text: more.
content.name: Zb2f

content.text: It is hard to talk about stress these days, as we know it has become a part of
content.name: v1KJ

content.text: life, but we should look for things we can do in order to feel better and
content.name: TGEH

content.text: protect our health in the long term.
content.name: NyAc

content.text: There are some strategies that require professional help, such as going to
content.name: IQy1

content.text: therapy or taking medication. Other techniques could help. For example, we
content.name: yCAZ

content.text: monitor our minds throughout the day and write down thoughts and moods
content.name: Vqep

content.text: to learn about the causes and find a way to cope with them.
content.name: X8Cu

content.text: Having good relationships with cheerful, optimistic, and understanding
content.name: veI8

content.text: people can help reduce our stress levels. We need that emotional support
content.name: vIVg

content.text: when we are going through tough times.
content.name: L8rV

content.text: Getting enough rest will help us deal with stress, as sleeping between six
content.name: 3tg4

content.text: and eight hours per night is recommended. In order to rest our minds, we
content.name: i3TN

content.text: should cut back on caffeine, remove the use of mobile phones or
content.name: 24Nj

content.text: electronic devices before going to bed, and, of course, the old time favorite:
content.name: DYZy

content.text: working out.
content.name: 9DIr

content.text: There are some other ways to cope with stress, but we can learn about it in
content.name: zfJs

content.text: our next article. Please message us on social media and tell us how you
content.name: Mw0Q

content.text: manage stress.
content.name: O97W
yGSd

content.textual:
The objective of this article is: 
To inform people about stress.
To give you a solution to stress.
To persuade you not to have stress.
To learn about stress.
A

What problems can stress cause? 
An automatic response developed in our ancestors
Major health problems, like heart disease and cancer.
Increase our blood pressure.
Major health problems, like cancer.
B

According to the text, what are some examples of simple challenges?
being mugged
paying bills and taxes
cooking a meal
starting a business
C

In line 15, what does “fight or flight “refer to?
To an alarm
To severe consequences for our healthy
a response
The body’s natural alarm system
D

What happens when we are under stress for a prolonged period of time?
It becomes chronic
You can have a stomachache
There is inflammation in the circulatory system.
harms your body.
A

In line 24, what does “wear and tear” refer to?
Clothes that are no longer used
The damage that happens to our bodies during a period of time
We are tearing our bodies apart
We must take care of the use we put on our body
B

In line 31, what does “it” refer to? 
period of time
changes in our routines
stress
bad habits
C

In line 47, What does “an old time favorite” mean?
working out
something that everyone knows
that working out is old
that it is a good idea to work out.
B
content.name: 2jSR
nJ3w

content.class: bg-slate-100 rounded p-3 my-2 max-w-3xl mx-auto
p-5 rounded-lg bg-sky-100 grid grid-cols-10 gap-5

content.text: Los ejercicios 26-33 se basan en la siguiente lectura
content.name: F2ss

content.text: Families are an essential part of who we are; they influence the values and
content.name: suUC

content.text: expectations of their children in two ways: directly and indirectly. Parents
content.name: 1Mkc

content.text: teach their children to differentiate between right and wrong, how they
content.name: egDp

content.text: interact with people, and rules and expectations. How parents socialize with
content.name: WIgH

content.text: their children shapes the way they interact with others.
content.name: 286Y

content.text: Family interactions can build up or destroy someone's self-confidence.
content.name: 4AkO

content.text: When families are united and communicative, they usually help children gain
content.name: iKyE

content.text: self-confidence and self-esteem. It has been observed that children who are
content.name: baf5

content.text: encouraged to pursue their choices grow up having a greater sense of
content.name: TgdR

content.text: confidence and individuality. Family activities like camping, traveling,
content.name: Plvn

content.text: taking classes, or retreats can also help children build self-confidence.
content.name: XkuO

content.text: There is confusion about being an involved parent without smothering, so
content.name: CMuA

content.text: we will go over helicopter parenting. This term was taken from teens who
content.name: S3Xc

content.text: said their parents would hover over them like a helicopter. There are similar
content.name: lkYG

content.text: terms like bulldozing parenting or cosseting parenting.
content.name: tTHo

content.text: A helicopter parent is a parenting style where mom and dad, or both of
content.name: ddUr

content.text: them, are highly involved in their kid's life. The focus on their child is so
content.name: ukJ3

content.text: intense that it can negatively impact a child's mental health. Children of
content.name: deUb

content.text: helicopter parents constantly shadow the child and don't allow them to have
content.name: VjDW

content.text: alone time.
content.name: L27C

content.text: In elementary school, most helicopter parents will ensure their child gets a
content.name: whMi

content.text: specific teacher, choose their child's friends and activities, and do their
content.name: WRUl

content.text: homework.
content.name: nPNk

content.text: Why are there helicopter parents? What causes helicopter parenting? There
content.name: cqS1

content.text: can be many causes. However, we will focus on anxiety,
content.name: eSyG

content.text: overcompensation, and peer pressure from other parents.
content.name: l9TS

content.text: When parents worry about the economy, their jobs, security, government,
content.name: UkFo

content.text: and everything in life, they may take control over their children's lives to
content.name: BcCY

content.text: protect them. They think they are empowered to keep their child from being
content.name: wrOc

content.text: hurt.
content.name: o91g

content.text: Now, some adults might have felt neglected or ignored when growing up
content.name: J1mY

content.text: could overcompensate with their children. This excessive monitoring could
content.name: W9FD

content.text: be an attempt to remedy their parents' deficiency in their upbringing.
content.name: PQSo

content.text: Sometimes, parents see other parents utterly involved with their children,
content.name: Ju9T

content.text: triggering a similar response. They may feel like bad parents if they are
content.name: 8U2n

content.text: not over-involved in their children's lives.
content.name: XYGa

content.text: Most helicopter parents start with good intentions, but there is a thin line
content.name: Ixre

content.text: between being engaged with our children and their lives, and we can lose
content.name: 0N0d

content.text: perspective on their needs.
content.name: nQrl

content.text: As previously mentioned, parents who are involved with their children
content.name: xr7v

content.text: bring many benefits for them, such as opportunities to grow or better
content.name: cPTc

content.text: self-confidence. But if we cross that thin line, children can be governed by
content.name: hQsV

content.text: fear, and decisions are made based on what might happen. Failure and
content.name: MHWn

content.text: challenges teach kids new skills and the certainty they can handle loss and
content.name: khgi

content.text: challenges.
content.name: KqAw

content.text: Some consequences of having helicopter parents can be decreased
content.name: l9tT

content.text: confidence and self-esteem, coping skills, anxiety, undeveloped life skills, or
content.name: URCY

content.text: a sense of entitlement.
content.name: xEf1

content.text: We want to take care of our children, but we don't want to neglect their
content.name: n2oF

content.text: ability to learn essential life skills. It is important to let our children
content.name: IEyH

content.text: struggle and be disappointed; in the end, we will help them work through
content.name: R1Ol

content.text: failure.
content.name: ibUC
g97u

content.textual:
The article was written by:
A parent
A psychologist
A student
A helicopter parent
A

How does the way parents socialize with their children affect their relationships?
They differentiate between right and wrong and learn about their rules and expectations.
The way parents and children socialize forms the way kids interact with other people.
They gain self-confidence and self-esteem.
Parent’s children can build or destroy their self-confidence.
B

In line 12, what does the word “smothering” mean?
Helping
releasing
Suffocating
dispersing
C

Where does the term “helicopter parent” mean?
A parenting style where parents are highly involved in their child’s life.
Cosseting parenting.
Teens said this about their parents.
Parents who don't leave their children alone.
A

Which are the causes for “helicopter parenting” the article mentions?
Parents who might have felt neglected or ignored when growing up.
Anxiety because of the world in general.
Good intentions without learning boundaries.
Anxiety, peer pressure and overcompensation
D

What happens if we cross the line between being involved and being overprotecting parents?
Children can act upon fear and all decisions are made based on possibilities.
Teaching failure to children and how to cope with it. 
Decreased confidence and self-esteem, anxiety, or a sense of entitlement.
They never learn about loss.
A

In lines 37-39, what does it refer to when it says, “they start with good intentions”?
To the good intentions of being helicopter parents.
That helicopter parents don’t mean to harm their kids.
Everything starts with good intentions.
Being a helicopter parent only comes from good intentions
B

What’s the author’s conclusion?
Helicopter parents shouldn’t exist as they harm their children’s lives.
There are helicopter parents that don’t know the damage they do to their offspring. 
If you are utterly involved with your child, he or she will suffer from anxiety when growing older.
It is important to take care of children and have a close relationship with them, however, there are boundaries we should respect
D
content.name: i4eN
DPI7

content.class: bg-slate-100 rounded p-3 my-2 max-w-3xl mx-auto
p-5 rounded-lg bg-sky-100 grid grid-cols-10 gap-5

content.text: Los ejercicios 34-45 se basan en la siguiente lectura.
content.name: e6sV

content.text: Talking about habits becomes a matter of whether to succeed in life or not.
content.name: yaS0

content.text: Habits are why you might be in shape or not, if you are happy or not, and
content.name: UOTd

content.text: your success in life.
content.name: QFxb

content.text: What we do daily, what we think daily, and how we proceed to do things
content.name: b4wS

content.text: shape our person. It would be best to learn how habits work to improve or
content.name: i1Wn

content.text: form new habits. This has to do with psychology, so learning about
content.name: RkdT

content.text: behaviorism and reading about Skinner, Pavlov, and the dog is a good idea.
content.name: E3Fw

content.text: The science behind forming habits comes from Pavlov, a Nobel prize winner
content.name: D2qJ

content.text: for his medical work. He worked primarily with dogs to research the
content.name: DnWi

content.text: digestive system. Pavlov measured the amount of saliva that dogs
content.name: y9xk

content.text: produce as part of digestion and noticed that dogs would salivate when they
content.name: LLRA

content.text: saw food, even before they tasted it. Then he noticed that other events that
content.name: vrXQ

content.text: were paired or related to food made the dogs start salivating. This is what
content.name: qwqy

content.text: we know as Classical conditioning.
content.name: xOXg

content.text: When you pair two things together (a stimulus and a response) and add
content.name: 5u3y

content.text: an additional stimulus, you can, at some point, remove the original stimulus
content.name: 8LRh

content.text: and then have the additional stimulus elicit the response.
content.name: 0Wnt

content.text: What does this have to do with habits? We are not dogs, but we certainly
content.name: lED6

content.text: respond to stimulus, and there is always a "response." For example, people
content.name: o3cJ

content.text: who drink alcohol as a response are mainly triggered by something in
content.name: V5zy

content.text: particular. It can be how someone talks to them or a specific flavor they
content.name: HDAF

content.text: taste. People who overeat may suffer from anxiety and can compulsively eat
content.name: XnSw

content.text: due to an email they read or something they heard.
content.name: 1pJ9

content.text: When it comes to creating or changing a habit, we should remember that
content.name: d6uL

content.text: small and specific actions are more likely to become habitual. If you
content.name: aWcr

content.text: want to start working out and say: "I will work every single day of my life" or
content.name: tu3q

content.text: "From now on, I'm going to work out a lot," it is unlikely to become a habit
content.name: PVlp

content.text: because it's a too general objective.
content.name: PuY1

content.text: If you start with small actions like working out three times a week as soon as
content.name: 8fN4

content.text: you get up from bed or say: "I will bounce on the trampoline from
content.name: PGCc

content.text: Monday to Friday at 7:00 for 20 minutes" it is specific, and it can work.
content.name: sBMe

content.text: An excellent tip to consider is that making the action attainable increases the
content.name: N0Jn

content.text: likelihood of becoming a habit. If we talk about exercise, you should make it
content.name: qVOM

content.text: easy for yourself: have your outfits ready the night before so you don't have
content.name: cCgo

content.text: to make any decisions that could get you on a detour from working out.
content.name: 4UBF

content.text: Habits that include visual or auditory cues will be easier to create and
content.name: ZaZe

content.text: maintain. An easy example of this is using our phones in the morning. As
content.name: u0pm

content.text: there is a buzz or noise, or the lights are too bright, they become cues that
content.name: QGUR

content.text: grab our attention and increase the likelihood that we will develop a
content.name: GHV4

content.text: conditioned response.
content.name: 0G3P

content.text: There are habits we would like to change, like smoking, overeating, eating
content.name: 81vT

content.text: ultra-processed foods, not working out. And, the best way to change a habit
content.name: mSm5

content.text: we don't like is to create a new one to replace it.
content.name: 1XTX

content.text: For example, if you have the habit of coming at the end of the day, grabbing
content.name: lho7

content.text: a beer and some chips, and turning the TV on to become a coach
content.name: GQma

content.text: potato for hours, you are most likely to realize you could have spent that
content.name: cjcc

content.text: time working out or doing something else that could help you with health.
content.name: hGnN

content.text: If you want to change that habit, you must return to the beginning of the
content.name: L0qc

content.text: stimulus/response cycle and replace the current response with a different
content.name: V36N

content.text: one.
content.name: eA39

content.text: Within seven days you will have conditioned walking into your house to a
content.name: 7t0n

content.text: different response, for example, working out.
content.name: 2hQY

content.text: It would help if you tried this: choosing a new habit you want to create or an
content.name: L8ZJ

content.text: existing one you want to change, then, think about the stimulus and
content.name: 6Jso

content.text: response. Make sure the action is small and attached to something
content.name: icxC

content.text: physical, and if possible, use visual or auditory cues.
content.name: UA6U

content.text: Habits can be easily confused with routines, so a habit is a response to an
content.name: qBjA

content.text: ingrained impulse, as opposed to routines, that involve repeated behavior.
content.name: Uk6Q

content.text: You may have a routine to wash the dishes without feeling an impulse to do
content.name: 4ZA0

content.text: it but because you need to do those things.
content.name: 6fLd

content.text: Breaking a habit can be difficult because that person may not be fully aware
content.name: NkVe

content.text: of how their habit works. If you are more conscious about habits and how
content.name: BuDP

content.text: they work, you should learn they don't come naturally. Some authors
content.name: Rdlq

content.text: mention that you need 21 or 90 days to break or create a new habit.
content.name: EnId

content.text: According to James Clear, the author of one of the best sellers on
content.name: 6pKa

content.text: habits, on average, it takes more than two months before a new behavior
content.name: oKUe

content.text: becomes automatic: 66 days.
content.name: xFm4

content.text: We should consider that new habit formation depends widely on the
content.name: wIGc

content.text: behavior, the person, and the circumstances.
content.name: 2Vma

content.text: Something helpful to keep in mind is to find inspiration in the long road,
content.name: qjGg

content.text: find people who are on the same or a similar path as yours, and follow their
content.name: dz4P

content.text: updates. You shouldn't judge yourself if you can't "create a habit" in 21 days.
content.name: bXyd

content.text: Start with Day 1 because that Day 1 can make a massive difference in the
content.name: eBPM

content.text: rest of your life.
content.name: hkam
1kLl

content.textual:
What is the text about?
Behaviorism
The way habits shape our life
How to create or change habits
Science behind habits
C

What is the relationship between habits and psychology?
Forming habits was discovered by Pavlov, who observed that dogs had a response to a certain stimulus
Learning about Skinner and Pavlov would help you understand it.
That Pavlov has a Nobel prize and that makes him trustworthy.
That stimulus and response are related.
A

What did he notice during his research on the digestive system?
That dogs needed their saliva to be measured.
That footsteps would make dogs salivate.
Classical conditioning. 
That dogs would salivate when they saw food, even before eating it.
D

In line 18, what does the author mean when he clarifies “we are not dogs”?
That we shouldn’t be treated like dogs.
That we respond to stimulus.
That even if the experiment was conducted on dogs, we also have this stimulus-response behavior. 
That dogs start salivating when we don’t.
C

According to the text, what may happen to a person that suffer from anxiety and receive an email that causes stress?
They may eat compulsively
They may drink alcohol
They may smoke
They may work out
A

What does the word “attainable” on line 32 could be substituted for?
reachable
impossible
unreachable
unreasonable
A

In line 35, what does the author mean when he uses the word “detour”?
That you get lost when driving
That you can go in another direction
That you are going to run away
That you will be confused
B

How can we develop a conditioned response?
Having outfits ready the night before
Using our phones to send a message
Using visual or auditory cues
Watching lights
C

What’s the best way to change a habit?
Creating a new habit to add to our routine.
It depends on the person.
Use 66 days of your life to change it
Go for it!
A

What is the difference between a habit and a routine?
They are easily confused
A habit is something you do without an impulse, so you do it all the time.
A habit is a response to an impulse and a routine is something you do without an impulse.
Routines are easier to stick to than habits.
A

Why can breaking a habit can be difficult?
Because you need more than 21 days
Lack of knowledge
Because you should read the book
Because it depends on your personality
B

What is the message of this text?
Learning more about habits can make a great difference in your life.
Changing habits little by little can help you make a difference in your life.
Learn more about psychology if you want to change your habits.
Breaking a habit or creating a new one depends on the person and the circumstances	
B
